## $2^{\circ}$. Expansion of the Solution in a Generalized Power Series.

The Bessel Equation. A point $x_0$ is called an ordinary point of the differential equation

$$
y'' + p(x) y' + q(x) y = 0
$$

if the coefficients $p(x)$ and $q(x)$ are holomorphic at this point; otherwise, the point $x_0$ is called a singular point of the differential equation (21).

A series of the form

$$
x^{\rho} \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} c_k x^k \quad (c_0 \neq 0)
$$

where $\rho$ is a given number, and the power series $\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} c_k x^k$ converges in some domain $|x| < R$, is called a generalized power series.

If $\rho$ is a non-negative integer, then the generalized power series (22) becomes an ordinary power series.

Theorem. If the point $x=0$ is a singular point of the equation (21), and the coefficients $p(x)$ and $q(x)$ of the equation can be represented as

$$
p(x) = \frac{\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} a_k x^k}{x}, \quad q(x) = \frac{\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} b_k x^k}{x^2}
$$

where the series in the numerators converge in some domain $|x| < R$, and the coefficients $a_0, b_0$, and $b_1$ are not all zero simultaneously, then the equation (21) has at least one solution in the form of a generalized power series

$$
y = x^{\rho} \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} c_k x^k \quad (c_0 \neq 0)
$$

which converges, at least, in the same domain $|x| < R$.

To determine the exponent $\rho$ and the coefficients $c_k$, one needs to substitute the series (22) into the equation (21), cancel by $x^{\rho}$, and set the coefficients of all powers of $x$ to zero (the method of undetermined coefficients).

The number $\rho$ is found from the so-called indicial equation

$$
\rho(\rho-1) + a_0 \rho + b_0 = 0
$$

where

$$
a_0 = \lim_{x \to 0} x p(x), \quad b_0 = \lim_{x \to 0} x^2 q(x)
$$

Let $\rho_1$ and $\rho_2$ be the roots of the indicial equation (23). We will consider three cases.

1. If the difference $\rho_1 - \rho_2$ is not an integer or zero, then two solutions of the form (22) can be constructed

$$
y_1 = x^{\rho_1} \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} c_k x^k \quad (c_0 \neq 0), \quad y_2 = x^{\rho_2} \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} A_k x^k \quad (A_0 \neq 0)
$$

2. If the difference $\rho_1 - \rho_2$ is a positive integer, then, generally speaking, only one series (solution of equation (21)) can be constructed

$$
y_1 = x^{\rho_1} \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} c_k x^k
$$

3. If the indicial equation (23) has a multiple root $\rho_1 = \rho_2$, then only one series - the solution (25) can be constructed. It is clear that in the first case, the constructed solutions $y_1(x)$ and $y_2(x)$ will be linearly independent (i.e., their ratio will not be a constant).

In the second and third cases, we have constructed only one solution. Note that if the difference $\rho_1 - \rho_2$ is a positive integer or zero, then in addition to the solution (25), the equation (21) will have a solution of the form

$$
y_2 = A y_1(x) \ln x + x^{\rho_2} \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} A_k x^k
$$

In this case, $y_2(x)$ contains an additional term of the form $A y_1(x) \ln x$, where $y_1(x)$ is given by (25).

Remark. The constant $A$ in (26) may turn out to be zero, and then for $y_2$ we will obtain an expression in the form of a generalized power series.

Example 4. Solve the system

$$

$$
original.solution:
Solution. The characteristic equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
1-\lambda & 2 \\
2 & -2-\lambda
\end{array}\right|=0, \text { or } \quad \lambda^{2}+\lambda-6=0
$$

The roots of the characteristic equation are $\lambda_{1}=2, \lambda_{2}=-3$. The general solution of the homogeneous system corresponding to system (15) is:

$$
\tilde{x}=2 C_{1} e^{2 t}+C_{2} e^{-3 t}, \quad \tilde{y}=C_{1} e^{2 t}-2 C_{2} e^{-3 t}
$$

We seek a particular solution of the non-homogeneous system of equations (15) in the form

$$
x_{\text {p }}=(A t+B) e^{t}, \quad y_{\text {p }}=(M t+N) e^{t}
$$

Substituting (16) into (15) and canceling $e^{t}$, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
A t+B+A & =A t+B+2 M t+2 N+16 t \\
M t+N+M & =2 A t+2 B-2 M t-2 N
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, $A=-12, B=-13, M=-8, N=-6$. Therefore,

$$
x_{\text {p }}=-(12 t+13) e^{t}, \quad y_{\text {p }}=-(8 t+6) e^{t}
$$

The general solution of the original system is:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x=\tilde{x}+x_{p}=2 C_{1} e^{2 t}+C_{2} e^{-3 t}-(12 t+13) e^{t} \\
& y=\tilde{y}+y_{p}=C_{1} e^{2 t}-2 C_{2} e^{-3 t}-(8 t+6) e^{t}
\end{aligned}
$$

$3^{\circ}$. Construction of Integrable Combinations (D'Alembert's Method). This method is used to construct integrable combinations when solving systems of linear equations with constant coefficients. Let's show its application for solving systems of two equations:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{d x}{d t}=a_{1} x+b_{1} y+f_{1}(t) \\
\frac{d y}{d t}=a_{2} x+b_{2} y+f_{2}(t)
\end{array}\right.
$$

Multiply the second equation by some number $\lambda$ and add it term by term to the first equation:

$$
\frac{d(x+\lambda y)}{d t}=\left(a_{1}+\lambda a_{2}\right) x+\left(b_{1}+\lambda b_{2}\right) y+f_{1}(t)+\lambda f_{2}(t)
$$

Rewrite the last equation as

$$
\frac{d(x+\lambda y)}{d t}=\left(a_{1}+\lambda a_{2}\right)\left(x+\frac{b_{1}+\lambda b_{2}}{a_{1}+\lambda a_{2}} y\right)+f_{1}(t)+\lambda f_{2}(t)
$$

Choose the number $\lambda$ such that

$$
\frac{b_{1}+\lambda b_{2}}{a_{1}+\lambda a_{2}}=\lambda
$$

Then (18) reduces to an equation linear in $x+\lambda y$

$$
\frac{d(x+\lambda y)}{d t}=\left(a_{1}+\lambda a_{2}\right)(x+\lambda y)+f_{1}(t)+\lambda f_{2}(t)
$$

Integrating which, we get

$$
x+\lambda y=e^{\left(a_{1}+\lambda a_{2}\right) t}\left\{C+\int\left[f_{1}(t)+\lambda f_{2}(t)\right] e^{-\left(a_{1}+\lambda a_{2}\right) t} d t\right\}
$$

If equation (19) has distinct real roots $\lambda_{1}$ and $\lambda_{2}$, then from (20) we obtain two first integrals of system (17), and thus the integration of this system is complete.

original.problem: 49. The picture is hung on the wall so that its lower edge is $a$ m, and the upper edge is $b$ m above the observer's eye. At what distance $x$ from the wall should the observer stand so that the picture is seen at the largest angle?
original.solution:
49. Let $A C=b, \quad A B=a, \quad A D=x$. From Fig. 30, it is clear that $b=x \operatorname{tg}(\alpha+\beta)=$ $=x \cdot \frac{\operatorname{tg} \alpha+\operatorname{tg} \beta}{1-\operatorname{tg} \alpha \operatorname{tg} \beta}$, but $\operatorname{tg} \beta=\frac{a}{x}$, then $\operatorname{tg} \alpha=$ $=\frac{b-a}{x+\frac{a b}{x}}$.

The maximum value of the viewing angle coincides with the maximum value of its tangent, i.e., with the maximum value of the fraction $\frac{b-a}{x+\frac{a b}{x}}$. Since $x \cdot \frac{a b}{x}=a b$, the minimum value of the sum $x+\frac{a b}{x}$ will be obtained when $x=\frac{a b}{x}$, i.e., $x=\sqrt{a b}$.

## Chapter 30. Series

f_{n}^{\prime}(x)=-\frac{\cos \frac{x}{2} \cos \frac{2 n+1}{2} x}{(4 n+2) \sin ^{2} \frac{x}{2}} \rightarrow 0
$$

Applying Lagrange's theorem to the function $f_{n}(y)$ on the interval between $x$ and $\pi$, we get $f_{n}(x)-f_{n}(\pi)=f_{n}^{\prime}(\xi)(x-\pi)$. As $n \rightarrow \infty$, this equality takes the form $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n} \sin n x+\frac{x}{2}-\frac{\pi}{2}=0$.

## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the function:

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(\frac{2^{2 x}-1}{x}\right)^{x+1}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(\frac{2^{2 x}-1}{x}\right)^{x+1}=\left(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2^{2 x}-1}{x}\right)^{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} x+1}= \\
& =\left(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2^{2 x}-1}{x}\right)^{0+1}=\left(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2^{2 x}-1}{x}\right)^{1}= \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\left(e^{\ln 2}\right)^{2 x}-1}{x}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{e^{2 x \ln 2}-1}{x}=
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$e^{2 x \ln 2}-1 \sim 2 x \ln 2$, as $x \rightarrow 0(2 x \ln 2 \rightarrow 0)$

We get:

$=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 x \ln 2}{x}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} 2 \ln 2=2 \ln 2$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the function:

$\lim _{x \rightarrow \frac{\pi}{2}}\left(\operatorname{ctg}\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)\right)^{\frac{1}{\cos x}}$
original.solution:
## Solution

Substitution:

$x=2 y+\frac{\pi}{2} \Rightarrow y=\frac{1}{2}\left(x-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)$

$x \rightarrow \frac{\pi}{2} \Rightarrow y \rightarrow 0$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{x \rightarrow \frac{\pi}{2}}\left(\operatorname{ctg}\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)\right)^{\frac{1}{\cos x}}=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}\left(\operatorname{ctg}\left(\frac{2 y+\frac{\pi}{2}}{2}\right)\right)^{\frac{1}{\cos \left(2 y+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)}}= \\
& =\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}\left(\operatorname{ctg}\left(y+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\right)^{-\frac{1}{\sin 2 y}}=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}\left(e^{\ln \left(\operatorname{ctg}\left(y+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\right)}\right)^{-\frac{1}{\sin 2 y}}= \\
& =\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} e^{-\frac{1}{\sin ^{2} 2 y} \cdot \ln \left(\operatorname{ctg}\left(y+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\right)}= \\
& =\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}-\frac{1}{\sin 2 y} \cdot \ln \left(\operatorname{ctg}\left(y+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\right)\right\}= \\
& =\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}-\frac{1}{\sin 2 y} \cdot \ln \left(\frac{1}{\operatorname{tg}\left(y+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)}\right)\right\}= \\
& =\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}-\frac{1}{\sin 2 y} \cdot \ln \left(\frac{1}{\left(\frac{\operatorname{tg} y+\operatorname{tg} \frac{\pi}{4}}{1-\operatorname{tg} y \cdot \operatorname{tg} \frac{\pi}{4}}\right)}\right)\right\}= \\
& =\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}-\frac{1}{\sin 2 y} \cdot \ln \left(\frac{1}{\left(\frac{\operatorname{tg} y+1}{1-\operatorname{tg} y \cdot y}\right)}\right)\right\}=
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}-\frac{1}{\sin 2 y} \cdot \ln \left(\frac{1-\operatorname{tg} y}{\operatorname{tg} y+1}\right)\right\}= \\
& =\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}-\frac{1}{\sin 2 y} \cdot \ln \left(1-\frac{2 \operatorname{tg} y}{\operatorname{tg} y+1}\right)\right\}=
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$\ln \left(1-\frac{2 \operatorname{tg} y}{\operatorname{tg} y+1}\right) \sim-\frac{2 \operatorname{tg} y}{1-\operatorname{tg} y}$, as $y \rightarrow 0\left(-\frac{2 \operatorname{tg} y}{1-\operatorname{tg} y} \rightarrow 0\right)$

$\sin 2 y \sim 2 y_{\text {, as }} y \rightarrow 0(2 y \rightarrow 0)$

We get:

$=\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}-\frac{1}{2 y} \cdot \frac{-2 \operatorname{tg} y}{\operatorname{tg} y+1}\right\}=$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$\operatorname{tg} y \sim y$, as $y \rightarrow 0$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{y} \cdot \frac{y}{\operatorname{tg} y+1}\right\}=\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{\operatorname{tg} y+1}\right\}= \\
& =\exp \left\{\frac{1}{\operatorname{tg} 0+1}\right\}=\exp \left\{\frac{1}{0+1}\right\}=\exp \{1\}=e
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{1}^{64} \frac{1-\sqrt[6]{x}+2 \sqrt[3]{x}}{x+2 \sqrt{x^{3}}+\sqrt[3]{x^{4}}} d x
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\int_{1}^{64} \frac{1-\sqrt[6]{x}+2 \sqrt[3]{x}}{x+2 \sqrt{x^{3}}+\sqrt[3]{x^{4}}} d x=
$$

Substitution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x=t^{6}, d x=6 t^{5} d t \\
& x=1 \Rightarrow t=\sqrt[6]{1}=1 \\
& x=64 \Rightarrow t=\sqrt[6]{64}=2
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
=\int_{1}^{2} \frac{\left(1-t+2 t^{2}\right) \cdot 6 t^{5} d t}{t^{6}+2 t^{9}+t^{8}}=6 \cdot \int_{1}^{2} \frac{2 t^{2}-t+1}{2 t^{4}+t^{3}+t} d t=
$$

Divide the denominator and numerator by \(2 t^{2}-t+1\):

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \begin{array}{ll}
2 t^{4}+t^{3}+t & \mid 2 t^{2}-t+1 \\
\frac{2 t^{4}-t^{3}+t^{2}}{2 t^{3}-t^{2}}+t & t^{2}+t
\end{array} \\
& \frac{2 t^{3}-t^{2}+t}{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =6 \cdot \int_{1}^{2} \frac{1}{t^{2}+t} d t=6 \cdot \int_{1}^{2} \frac{1}{t(t+1)} d t=6 \cdot \int_{1}^{2}\left(\frac{1}{t}-\frac{1}{t+1}\right) d t= \\
& =\left.6 \cdot(\ln |t|-\ln |t+1|)\right|_{1} ^{2}=6 \cdot(\ln |2|-\ln |2+1|)-6 \cdot(\ln |1|-\ln |1+1|)= \\
& =6 \ln 2-6 \ln 3-6 \cdot 0+6 \ln 2=6 \ln \frac{4}{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{0}^{5} e^{\sqrt{(5-x) /(5+x)}} \cdot \frac{d x}{(5+x) \sqrt{25-x^{2}}}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\int_{0}^{5} e^{\sqrt{(5-x) /(5+x)}} \cdot \frac{d x}{(5+x) \sqrt{25-x^{2}}}=
$$

Substitution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& t=\sqrt{\frac{5-x}{5+x}} \\
& d t=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{5+x}{5-x}} \cdot\left(\frac{5-x}{5+x}\right)^{\prime} \cdot d x=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{5+x}{5-x}} \cdot \frac{-10}{(5+x)^{2}} \cdot d x=-\frac{5 d x}{\sqrt{25-x^{2}}(5+x)} \\
& x=0 \Rightarrow t=\sqrt{\frac{5-0}{5+0}}=1 \\
& x=5 \Rightarrow t=\sqrt{\frac{5-5}{5+5}}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
=\int_{1}^{0} e^{t} \cdot\left(\frac{-d t}{5}\right)=-\frac{1}{5} \cdot \int_{1}^{0} e^{t} d t=-\left.\frac{e^{t}}{5}\right|_{1} ^{0}=-\frac{e^{0}}{5}+\frac{e^{1}}{5}=\frac{e-1}{5}
$$

$$
original.solution:
## Solution

11.10. $\int_{1}^{2} \frac{x+\sqrt{3 x-2}-10}{\sqrt{3 x-2}+7} d x=$

saucera: $\sqrt{3 x-2}=t \Rightarrow x=\frac{1}{3}\left(t^{2}+2\right)$, $d x=\frac{2}{3} t d t$

$=\frac{2}{3} \int_{1}^{2} \frac{\frac{1}{3}\left(t^{2}+2\right)+t-10}{t+7} t d t=\frac{2}{9} \int_{1}^{2} \frac{t^{3}+3 t^{2}-28 t}{t+7} d t=$

$=\frac{2}{9} \int_{1}^{2}\left(t^{2}-4 t\right) d t=\left.\frac{2}{9}\left(\frac{1}{3} t^{3}-2 t^{2}\right)\right|_{1} ^{2}=$

$=\frac{2}{9}\left(\frac{8}{3}-8-\frac{1}{3}+2\right)=-\frac{22}{27}$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{6}^{10} \sqrt{\frac{4-x}{x-12}} d x
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\int_{6}^{10} \sqrt{\frac{4-x}{x-12}} d x=
$$

Substitution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& t=\sqrt{\frac{4-x}{x-12}} \Rightarrow t^{2}=\frac{4-x}{x-12}=-\frac{x-12+8}{x-12}=-1-\frac{8}{x-12} \Rightarrow \\
& \Rightarrow 12-x=\frac{8}{t^{2}+1} \Rightarrow x=-\frac{8}{t^{2}+1}+12 \\
& d x=\frac{8}{\left(t^{2}+1\right)^{2}} \cdot 2 t \cdot d t=\frac{16 t}{\left(t^{2}+1\right)^{2}} \cdot d t \\
& x=6 \Rightarrow t=\sqrt{\frac{4-6}{6-12}}=\sqrt{\frac{-2}{-6}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \\
& x=10 \Rightarrow t=\sqrt{\frac{4-10}{10-12}}=\sqrt{\frac{-6}{-2}}=\sqrt{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
=\int_{\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}}^{\sqrt{3}} t \cdot \frac{16 t}{\left(t^{2}+1\right)^{2}} \cdot d t=
$$

Substitution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& t=\tan z, d t=\frac{d z}{\cos ^{2} z} \\
& t=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \Rightarrow z=\arctan \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}=\frac{\pi}{6} \\
& t=\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow z=\arctan \sqrt{3}=\frac{\pi}{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =16 \cdot \int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3} \frac{\tan^{2} z}{\left(\tan^{2} z+1\right)^{2}} \cdot \frac{d z}{\cos ^{2} z}=16 \cdot \int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3} \frac{\tan^{2} z}{\left(\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} z}\right)^{2}} \cdot \frac{d z}{\cos ^{2} z}=16 \cdot \int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3} \tan^{2} z \cdot \cos ^{2} z \cdot d z= \\
& =16 \cdot \int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3} \sin ^{2} z \cdot d z=8 \cdot \int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3}(1-\cos 2 z) d z=\left.8 \cdot\left(z-\frac{\sin 2 z}{2}\right)\right|_{\pi / 6} ^{\pi / 3}= \\
& =8 \cdot\left(\frac{\pi}{3}-\frac{\sin \frac{2 \pi}{3}}{2}\right)-8 \cdot\left(\frac{\pi}{6}-\frac{\sin \frac{2 \pi}{6}}{2}\right)=\frac{8 \pi}{3}-4 \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{4 \pi}{3}+4 \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}=\frac{4 \pi}{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Approximately calculate using the differential.

$y=\arcsin x, x=0.08$
original.solution:
## Solution

If the increment $\Delta x = x - x_{0 \text{ of the argument }} x$ is small in absolute value, then

$f(x) = f\left(x_{0} + \Delta x\right) \approx f\left(x_{0}\right) + f^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right) \cdot \Delta x$

Choose:

$x_{0} = 0$

Then:

$\Delta x = 0.08$

Calculate:

$y(0) = \arcsin 0 = 0$

$y^{\prime} = (\arcsin x)^{\prime} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - x^{2}}}$
$y^{\prime}(0) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - 0^{2}}} = 1$

We get:

$y(0.08) \approx y(0) + y^{\prime}(0) \cdot 0.08 = 0 + 1 \cdot 0.08 = 0.08$

## Task Condition

Approximately calculate using the differential.

$$
y=\sqrt[3]{x}, x=1,21
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

If the increment $\Delta x = x - x_{\text{argument}}: x$ is small in absolute value, then

$$
f(x) = f\left(x_{0} + \Delta x\right) \approx f\left(x_{0}\right) + f^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right) \cdot \Delta x
$$

Choose:

$x_{0} = 1$

Then:

$\Delta x = 0.21$

## Calculation:

$$
y(1) = \sqrt[3]{1} = 1
$$

$y^{\prime} = (\sqrt[3]{x})^{\prime} = \left(x^{\frac{1}{3}}\right)^{\prime} = \frac{1}{3} x^{-\frac{2}{3}}$

$y^{\prime}(1) = \frac{1}{3} \cdot 1^{-\frac{2}{3}} = \frac{1}{3}$

We get:

$y(1.21) \approx y(1) + y^{\prime}(1) \cdot 0.21 = 1 + \frac{1}{3} \cdot 0.21 = 1.0^{-}$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the indefinite integral:

$$
\int \frac{x^{3}+6 x^{2}+18 x-4}{(x-2)(x+2)^{3}} d x
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\int \frac{x^{3}+6 x^{2}+18 x-4}{(x-2)(x+2)^{3}} d x=
$$

We decompose the proper rational fraction into partial fractions using the method of undetermined coefficients:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{x^{3}+6 x^{2}+18 x-4}{(x-2)(x+2)^{3}}=\frac{A}{x-2}+\frac{B_{1}}{x+2}+\frac{B_{2}}{(x+2)^{2}}+\frac{B_{3}}{(x+2)^{3}}= \\
& =\frac{A(x+2)^{3}+B_{1}(x-2)(x+2)^{2}+B_{2}(x-2)(x+2)+B_{3}(x-2)}{(x-2)(x+2)^{3}}= \\
& =\frac{A\left(x^{3}+6 x^{2}+12 x+8\right)+B_{1}\left(x^{3}+2 x^{2}-4 x-8\right)+B_{2}\left(x^{2}-4\right)+B_{3}(x-2)}{(x-2)(x+2)^{3}}= \\
& =\frac{\left(A+B_{1}\right) x^{3}+\left(6 A+2 B_{1}+B_{2}\right) x^{2}+\left(12 A-4 B_{1}+B_{3}\right) x+\left(8 A-8 B_{1}-4 B_{2}-2 B_{3}\right)}{(x-2)(x+2)^{3}} \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
A+B_{1}=1 \\
6 A+2 B_{1}+B_{2}=6 \\
12 A-4 B_{1}+B_{3}=18 \\
8 A-8 B_{1}-4 B_{2}-2 B_{3}=-4
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Add the third equation multiplied by 2 to the fourth equation:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
A+B_{1}=1 \\
6 A+2 B_{1}+B_{2}=6 \\
12 A-4 B_{1}+B_{3}=18 \\
32 A-16 B_{1}-4 B_{2}=32
\end{array}\right.
$$

Add the second equation multiplied by 4 to the fourth equation:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
A+B_{1}=1 \\
6 A+2 B_{1}+B_{2}=6 \\
12 A-4 B_{1}+B_{3}=18 \\
56 A-8 B_{1}=56
\end{array}\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
A+B_{1}=1 \\
6 A+2 B_{1}+B_{2}=6 \\
12 A-4 B_{1}+B_{3}=18 \\
7 A-B_{1}=7
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Add the first equation to the fourth equation:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
A+B_{1}=1 \\
6 A+2 B_{1}+B_{2}=6 \\
12 A-4 B_{1}+B_{3}=18 \\
8 A=8
\end{array}\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
B_{1}=0 \\
2 B_{1}+B_{2}=0 \\
-4 B_{1}+B_{3}=6 \\
A=1
\end{array}\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
B_{1}=0 \\
B_{2}=0 \\
B_{3}=6 \\
A=1
\end{array}\right. \\
& \frac{x^{3}+6 x^{2}+4 x+24}{(x-2)(x+2)^{3}}=\frac{1}{x-2}+\frac{6}{(x+2)^{3}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then:

$$
\int \frac{x^{3}+6 x^{2}+18 x-4}{(x-2)(x+2)^{3}} d x=\int\left(\frac{1}{x-2}+\frac{6}{(x+2)^{3}}\right) d x=\ln |x-2|-\frac{3}{(x+2)^{2}}+C
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the numerical sequence:
$\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)}-\sqrt{n^{6}-1}}{n}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)}-\sqrt{n^{6}-1}}{n}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\left(\sqrt{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)}-\sqrt{n^{6}-1}\right)\left(\sqrt{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)}+\sqrt{n^{6}-1}\right)}{n\left(\sqrt{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)}+\sqrt{n^{6}-1}\right)}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)-\left(n^{6}-1\right)}{n\left(\sqrt{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)}+\sqrt{n^{6}-1}\right)}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n^{6}-n^{4}+n^{2}-1-n^{6}+1}{n\left(\sqrt{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)}+\sqrt{n^{6}-1}\right)}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{-n^{4}+n^{2}}{n\left(\sqrt{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)}+\sqrt{n^{6}-1}\right)}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\frac{1}{n^{4}}\left(-n^{4}+n^{2}\right)}{\frac{1}{n^{4}} n\left(\sqrt{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)}+\sqrt{n^{6}-1}\right)}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{-1+\frac{1}{n^{2}}}{\frac{1}{n^{3}} \sqrt{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)}+\frac{1}{n^{3}} \sqrt{n^{6}-1}}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{-1+\frac{1}{n^{2}}}{\sqrt{\left(1+\frac{1}{n^{4}}\right)\left(1-\frac{1}{n^{2}}\right)}+\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{n^{6}}}}=\frac{-1+0}{\sqrt{(1+0)(1-0)}+\sqrt{1-0}}=-\frac{1}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

A cylinder is filled with gas at atmospheric pressure (103.3 kPa). Assuming the gas is ideal, determine the work (in joules) during the isothermal compression of the gas by a piston moving inside the cylinder by $h$ meters (see figure).

Hint: The equation of state of the gas

$\rho V=$ const, where $\rho$ - pressure, $V$ - volume.

$$
H=1.6 \mathrm{m}, h=0.8 \mathrm{m}, R=0.3 \mathrm{m}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_31c1f87d4364af4121d5g-47.jpg?height=514&width=834&top_left_y=622&top_left_x=1088)
original.solution:
## Solution

Piston area: $S=\pi R^{2}$

Volume of gas during compression: $V(x)=S \cdot(H-x) ; 0 \leq x \leq h$

Pressure of gas during compression: $p(x)=\frac{p_{0} \cdot S \cdot H}{V(x)}$

Force of pressure on the piston: $F(x)=p(x) \cdot S$

By definition, the elementary work $\Delta A=F(x) \Delta x \Rightarrow$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow d A=\frac{p_{0} \cdot S \cdot H}{S \cdot(H-x)} \cdot S d x=\frac{p_{0} \cdot S \cdot H}{H-x} d x \Rightarrow \\
& \Rightarrow A=\int_{0}^{h} \frac{p_{0} \cdot S \cdot H}{H-x} d x=-\int_{0}^{h} \frac{p_{0} \cdot S \cdot H}{H-x} d(H-x)=-\left.p_{0} \cdot S \cdot H \cdot \ln (H-x)\right|_{0} ^{h}= \\
& =p_{0} \cdot S \cdot H \cdot \ln \left(\frac{H}{H-h}\right)=p_{0} \cdot \pi \cdot R^{2} \cdot H \cdot \ln \left(\frac{H}{H-h}\right) \\
& =\pi \cdot(0.3[m])^{2} \cdot 103.3[k P a] \cdot 1.6[m] \cdot \ln \left(\frac{1.6[m]}{1.6[m]-0.8[m]}\right)=32392 \approx 32400[ \\
& \text { kJ] }
\end{aligned}
$$

Source — "http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\� \%D0\%9A\%D1\%83\%D0\%B7\%D0\%BD\%D0\%B5\%D1\%86\%D0\%BE\%D0\%B2_\%D0\%98\%D0\%BD $\% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 82 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 3 \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 80 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 0 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{BB} \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 8 \mathrm{~B}+22-29$ "

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by equations in a rectangular coordinate system.

$$
y=\ln \left(1-x^{2}\right), 0 \leq x \leq \frac{1}{4}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

The length of the arc of a curve defined by the equation $y=f(x) ; a \leq x \leq b$ is given by the formula

$$
L=\int_{a}^{b} \sqrt{1+\left(f^{\prime}(x)\right)^{2}} d x
$$

Let's find the derivative of the given function:

$$
f^{\prime}(x)=\left(\ln \left(1-x^{2}\right)\right)^{\prime}=\frac{1}{1-x^{2}}\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{-2 x}{1-x^{2}}
$$

Then, using the formula above, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
L & =\int_{0}^{1 / 4} \sqrt{1+\left(-\frac{2 x}{1-x^{2}}\right)^{2}} d x= \\
& =\int_{0}^{1 / 4} \sqrt{1+\frac{4 x^{2}}{\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{2}}} d x= \\
& =\int_{0}^{1 / 4} \sqrt{\frac{1-2 x^{2}+x^{4}+4 x^{2}}{\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{2}}} d x= \\
& =\int_{0}^{1 / 4} \sqrt{\frac{x^{4}+2 x^{2}+1}{\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{2}}} d x= \\
& =\int_{0}^{1 / 4} \sqrt{\frac{\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{2}}{\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{2}} d x}= \\
& =-\int_{0}^{1 / 4} \frac{x^{2}+1}{x^{2}-1} d x= \\
& =-\int_{0}^{1 / 4} \frac{x^{2}-1+1+1}{x^{2}-1} d x= \\
& =-\int_{0}^{1 / 4} \frac{x^{2}-1}{x^{2}-1} d x-2 \int_{0}^{1 / 4} \frac{1}{x^{2}-1} d x= \\
& =-\left.x\right|_{0} ^{1 / 4} \frac{-\left.2\left(\frac{1}{2} \ln \left|\frac{x-1}{x+1}\right|\right)\right|_{0} ^{1 / 4}=-\left(\frac{1}{4}-0\right)-\left(\ln \frac{3}{5}-\ln \frac{1}{1}\right)=\ln \frac{5}{3}-\frac{1}{4}}{x_{0}^{2}} d x=
\end{aligned}
$$

Source — "http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/%D0%9A%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BE%D0%B2_%D0%98%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8B_%D0%97%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%87%D0%B0_17-10" Categories: Kuznetsov's Problem Book Integrals Problem 17 | Integrals

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by equations in a rectangular coordinate system.

$$
y=\frac{1-e^{x}-e^{-x}}{2}, 0 \leq x \leq 3
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

The length of the arc of a curve defined by the equation $y=f(x) ; a \leq x \leq b$ is given by the formula

$$
L=\int_{a}^{b} \sqrt{1+\left(f^{\prime}(x)\right)^{2}} d x
$$

Let's find the derivative of the given function:

$$
f^{\prime}(x)=\left(\frac{1-e^{x}-e^{-x}}{2}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2} \cdot\left(-e^{x}+e^{-x}\right)
$$

Then, using the formula above, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
L & =\int_{0}^{3} \sqrt{1+\frac{1}{4} \cdot\left(-e^{x}+e^{-x}\right)^{2}} d x= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{3} \sqrt{4+\left(-e^{x}+e^{-x}\right)^{2}} d x= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{3} \sqrt{4+e^{2 x}-2+e^{-2 x}} d x= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{3} \sqrt{e^{2 x}+2+e^{-2 x}} d x= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{3} \sqrt{\left(e^{x}+e^{-x}\right)^{2}} d x= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{3}\left(e^{x}+e^{-x}\right) d x= \\
& =\left.\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{x}-e^{-x}\right)\right|_{0} ^{3}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\left(e^{3}-e^{0}\right)-\left(e^{-3}-e^{0}\right)\right)=\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{3}-e^{-3}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Source — «http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\� \%D0\%9A\%D1\%83\%D0\%B7\%D0\%BD\%D0\%B5\%D1\%86\%D0\%BE\%D0\%B2_\%D0\%98\%D0\%BD $\% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 82 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 5 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 3 \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 80 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 0 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{BB} \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 8 \mathrm{~B}+17-31$ » Categories: Kuznetsov's Problem Book Integrals Problem 17 | Integrals

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the function:

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(1+\tan^{2} x\right)^{\frac{1}{\ln \left(1+3 x^{2}\right)}}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(1+\tan ^{2} x\right)^{\frac{1}{\ln \left(1+3 x^{2}\right)}}=$

$=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(e^{\ln \left(1+\tan ^{2} x\right)}\right)^{\frac{1}{\ln \left(1+3 x^{2}\right)}}=$

$=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} e^{\frac{\ln \left(1+\tan ^{2} x\right)}{\ln \left(1+3 x^{2}\right)}}=$

$=\exp \left\{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\ln \left(1+\tan ^{2} x\right)}{\ln \left(1+3 x^{2}\right)}\right\}=$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \ln \left(1+\tan ^{2} x\right) \sim \tan ^{2} x, \text { as } x \rightarrow 0\left(\tan ^{2} x \rightarrow 0\right) \\
& \ln \left(1+3 x^{2}\right) \sim 3 x^{2}, \text { as } x \rightarrow 0\left(3 x^{2} \rightarrow 0\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
=\exp \left\{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\tan ^{2} x}{3 x^{2}}\right\}=
$$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$\tan x \sim x$, as $x \rightarrow 0$

We get:

$=\exp \left\{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x^{2}}{3 x^{2}}\right\}=\exp \left\{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{3}\right\}=e^{\frac{1}{3}}$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{\sqrt{2}}^{2 \sqrt{2}} \frac{\sqrt{x^{2}-2}}{x^{4}} d x
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\int_{\sqrt{2}}^{2 \sqrt{2}} \frac{\sqrt{x^{2}-2}}{x^{4}} d x=
$$

Substitution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{\sin t} \Rightarrow d x=-\frac{\sqrt{2}}{\sin ^{2} t} \cdot \cos t d t=-\frac{\sqrt{2} \cos t d t}{\sin ^{2} t} \\
& x=\sqrt{2} \Rightarrow t=\arcsin \frac{\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{2}}=\frac{\pi}{2} \\
& x=2 \sqrt{2} \Rightarrow t=\arcsin \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2 \sqrt{2}}=\frac{\pi}{6}
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\int_{\pi / 2}^{\pi / 6} \frac{\sqrt{\frac{2}{\sin ^{2} t}-2}}{\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{\sin t}\right)^{4}} \cdot\left(-\frac{\sqrt{2} \cos t d t}{\sin ^{2} t}\right)=\int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\sin ^{4} t}{4} \cdot \sqrt{2} \sqrt{\frac{1-\sin ^{2} t}{\sin ^{2} t}} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2} \cos t d t}{\sin ^{2} t}= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 2} \sin ^{2} t \cdot \sqrt{\frac{\cos ^{2} t}{\sin ^{2} t}} \cdot \cos t d t=\frac{1}{2} \int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 2} \sin ^{2} t \cdot \frac{\cos t}{\sin t} \cdot \cos t d t= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 2} \sin t \cdot \cos ^{2} t d t=-\frac{1}{2} \int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 2} \cos ^{2} t d(\cos t)=-\left.\frac{\cos ^{3} t}{6}\right|_{\pi / 6} ^{\pi / 2}= \\
& =-\frac{\cos ^{3} \frac{\pi}{2}}{6}+\frac{\cos ^{3} \frac{\pi}{6}}{6}=-\frac{0^{3}}{6}+\frac{\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)^{3}}{6}=0+\frac{\left(\frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{8}\right)}{6}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{16}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{0}^{2} \frac{x^{4} \cdot d x}{\sqrt{\left(8-x^{2}\right)^{3}}}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\int_{0}^{2} \frac{x^{4} \cdot d x}{\sqrt{\left(8-x^{2}\right)^{3}}}=\int_{0}^{2} \frac{x^{4} \cdot d x}{\left(8-x^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}}=
$$

Substitution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x=2 \sqrt{2} \sin t \Rightarrow d x=2 \sqrt{2} \cos t d t \\
& x=0 \Rightarrow t=\arcsin \frac{0}{2 \sqrt{2}}=0 \\
& x=2 \Rightarrow t=\arcsin \frac{2}{2 \sqrt{2}}=\arcsin \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}=\frac{\pi}{4}
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\int_{0}^{\pi / 4} \frac{64 \sin ^{4} t \cdot 2 \sqrt{2} \cos t}{\sqrt{\left(8-8 \sin ^{2} t\right)^{3}}} d t=\int_{0}^{\pi / 4} \frac{64 \sin ^{4} t \cdot 2 \sqrt{2} \cos t}{16 \sqrt{2} \cos ^{3} t} d t=8 \cdot \int_{0}^{\pi / 4} \frac{\sin ^{4} t}{\cos ^{2} t} d t= \\
& =8 \cdot \int_{0}^{\pi / 4} \frac{\left(1-\cos ^{2} t\right)^{2}}{\cos ^{2} t} d t=8 \cdot \int_{0}^{\pi / 4} \frac{1-2 \cos ^{2} t+\cos ^{4} t}{\cos ^{2} t} d t= \\
& =8 \cdot \int_{0}^{\pi / 4}\left(\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} t}-2+\frac{1+\cos 2 t}{2}\right) d t=8 \cdot \int_{0}^{\pi / 4}\left(\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} t}-\frac{3}{2}+\frac{1}{2} \cos 2 t\right) d t= \\
& =\left.8\left(\operatorname{tg} t-\frac{3 t}{2}+\frac{1}{4} \sin 2 t\right)\right|_{0} ^{\pi / 4}=8\left(\operatorname{tg} \frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{3 \pi}{8}+\frac{1}{4} \sin \frac{\pi}{2}\right)-8\left(\operatorname{tg} 0-\frac{3 \cdot 0}{2}+\frac{1}{4} \sin 0\right)= \\
& =8\left(1-\frac{3 \pi}{8}+\frac{1}{4} \cdot 1\right)-8\left(2 \cdot 0-0+\frac{1}{4} \cdot 0\right)=8\left(\frac{5}{4}-\frac{3 \pi}{8}\right)=10-3 \pi
\end{aligned}
$$

Source — «http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�_\�\� \%D1\%83\%D0\%B7\%D0\%BD\%D0\%B5\%D1\%86\%D0\%BE\%D0\%B2_\%D0\%98\%D0\%BD\%D1\%82\%D0\%B5 $\% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 3 \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 80 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 0 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{BB} \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 8 \mathrm{~B}+12-23$ »

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the function:

$\lim _{x \rightarrow \frac{\pi}{2}}(1+\cos 3 x)^{\sec x}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$\lim _{x \rightarrow \frac{\pi}{2}}(1+\cos 3 x)^{\sec x}=\lim _{x \rightarrow \frac{\pi}{2}}(1+\cos 3 x)^{\frac{1}{\cos x}}=$

Substitution:

$x=y+\frac{\pi}{2} \Rightarrow y=x-\frac{\pi}{2}$

$x \rightarrow \frac{\pi}{2} \Rightarrow y \rightarrow 0$

We get:

$=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}\left(1+\cos 3\left(y+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\right)^{\frac{1}{\cos \left(y+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)}}=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}\left(1+\cos \left(3 y+\frac{3 \pi}{2}\right)\right)^{-\frac{1}{\sin y}}=$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}(1+\sin 3 y)^{-\frac{1}{\sin y}}=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}\left(e^{\ln (1+\sin 3 y)}\right)^{-\frac{1}{\sin y}}= \\
& =\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} e^{-\frac{1}{\sin y} \cdot \ln (1+\sin 3 y)}=\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}-\frac{1}{\sin y} \cdot \ln (1+\sin 3 y)\right\}=
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$\ln (1+\sin 3 y) \sim \sin 3 y_{\text {, as }} y \rightarrow 0(\sin 3 y \rightarrow 0)$

$\sin y \sim y$, as $y \rightarrow 0$

We get:

$=\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}-\frac{1}{y} \cdot \sin 3 y\right\}=$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$\sin 3 y \sim 3 y_{\text {, as }} y \rightarrow 0(3 y \rightarrow 0)$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}-\frac{1}{y} \cdot 3 y\right\}=\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}-3\right\}= \\
& =\exp \{-3\}=e^{-3}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the function:

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{e^{2 x}-e^{-5 x}}{2 \sin x-\tan x}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{e^{2 x}-e^{-5 x}}{2 \sin x-\tan x}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\left(e^{2 x}-1\right)-\left(e^{-5 x}-1\right)}{2 \sin x-\tan x}=$
$=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\frac{1}{x}\left(\left(e^{2 x}-1\right)-\left(e^{-5 x}-1\right)\right)}{\frac{1}{x}(2 \sin x-\tan x)}=$
$=\frac{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{x}\left(\left(e^{2 x}-1\right)-\left(e^{-5 x}-1\right)\right)}{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{x}(2 \sin x-\tan x)}=$
$=\left(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{e^{2 x}-1}{x}-\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{e^{-5 x}-1}{x}\right) /\left(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 \sin x}{x}-\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\tan x}{x}\right)=$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$e^{2 x}-1 \sim 2 x$, as $x \rightarrow 0(2 x \rightarrow 0)$

$e^{-5 x}-1 \sim -5 x$, as $x \rightarrow 0(-5 x \rightarrow 0)$

$\sin x \sim x$, as $x \rightarrow 0$

$\tan x \sim x$, as $x \rightarrow 0$

We get:

$=\frac{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 x}{x}-\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{-5 x}{x}}{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 x}{x}-\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x}{x}}=\frac{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} 2-\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}-5}{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} 2-\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} 1}=\frac{2+5}{2-1}=7$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the function:

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \sqrt[x^{2}]{2-\cos x}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \sqrt[x^{2}]{2-\cos x}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}(2-\cos x)^{\frac{1}{x^{2}}}=$

$=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(e^{\ln (2-\cos x)}\right)^{\frac{1}{x^{2}}}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} e^{\frac{\ln (2-\cos x)}{x^{2}}}=$

$=\exp \left\{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\ln (1+(1-\cos x))}{x^{2}}\right\}=$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$\ln (1+(1-\cos x)) \sim 1-\cos x$, as $x \rightarrow 0(1-\cos x \rightarrow 0)$

We get:

$=\exp \left\{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1-\cos x}{x^{2}}\right\}=$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:
$1-\cos x \sim \frac{x^{2}}{2}$, as $x \rightarrow 0$

We get:

$=\exp \left\{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\frac{x^{2}}{2}}{x^{2}}\right\}=\exp \left\{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{2}\right\}=e^{\frac{1}{2}}=\sqrt{e}$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{0} \frac{\sin x d x}{(1+\cos x-\sin x)^{2}}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

We will use the universal substitution:

$$
t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{x}{2}
$$

From which:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sin x=\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}}, \cos x=\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}, d x=\frac{2 d t}{1+t^{2}} \\
& x=-\frac{\pi}{2} \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{\left(-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)}{2}=\operatorname{tg}\left(-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)=-1 \\
& x=0 \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{0}{2}=\operatorname{tg} 0=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{0} \frac{\sin x d x}{(1+\cos x-\sin x)^{2}}=\int_{-1}^{0} \frac{\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}} \cdot \frac{2 d t}{1+t^{2}}}{\left(1+\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}-\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}}\right)^{2}}=\int_{-1}^{0} \frac{\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}} \cdot \frac{2 d t}{1+t^{2}}}{\left(\frac{1+t^{2}+1-t^{2}-2 t}{1+t^{2}}\right)^{2}}= \\
& =\int_{-1}^{0} \frac{4 t \cdot d t}{(2-2 t)^{2}}=\int_{-1}^{0} \frac{t \cdot d t}{(1-t)^{2}}=
\end{aligned}
$$

Substitution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u=1-t, d t=-d u \\
& t=-1 \Rightarrow u=2 \\
& t=0 \Rightarrow u=1
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
=-\int_{2}^{1} \frac{(1-u) d u}{u^{2}}=\int_{1}^{2}\left(\frac{1}{u^{2}}-\frac{1}{u}\right) d u=
$$

$$
=-\frac{1}{u}-\left.\ln |u|\right|_{1} ^{2}=-\frac{1}{2}-\ln |2|+\frac{1}{1}+\ln |1|=\frac{1}{2}-\ln 2
$$

Source — «http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/%D0%9A%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BE%D0%B2_%D0%98%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8B_8-23» Categories: Kuznetsov's Problem Book Integrals Problem 8 | Integrals

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the function:

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(5-\frac{4}{\cos x}\right)^{\frac{1}{\sin ^{2} 3 x}}$
original.solution:
## Solution

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(5-\frac{4}{\cos x}\right)^{\frac{1}{\sin ^{2} 3 x}}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(e^{\ln \left(5-\frac{4}{\cos x}\right)}\right)^{\frac{1}{\sin ^{2} 3 x}}=$
$=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} e^{\frac{\ln \left(5-\frac{4}{\cos x}\right)}{\sin ^{2} 3 x}}=\exp \left\{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\ln \left(1+\left(4-\frac{4}{\cos x}\right)\right)}{\sin ^{2} 3 x}\right\}=$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$\ln \left(1+\left(4-\frac{4}{\cos x}\right)\right) \sim 4-\frac{4}{\cos x}$, as $\quad x \rightarrow 0\left(4-\frac{4}{\cos x} \rightarrow 0\right)$

$\sin 3 x \sim 3 x$, as $x \rightarrow 0(3 x \rightarrow 0)$

We get:

$=\exp \left\{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{4-\frac{4}{\cos x}}{(3 x)^{2}}\right\}=\exp \left\{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{4\left(\frac{\cos x}{\cos x}-\frac{1}{\cos x}\right)}{9 x^{2}}\right\}=$

$=\exp \left\{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{-4(1-\cos x)}{9 x^{2} \cdot \cos x}\right\}=$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$1-\cos x \sim \frac{x^{2}}{2}$, as $x \rightarrow 0$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\exp \left\{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{-4 \cdot \frac{x^{2}}{2}}{9 x^{2} \cdot \cos x}\right\}=\exp \left\{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{-2}{9 \cdot \cos x}\right\}= \\
& =\exp \left\{\frac{-2}{9 \cdot \cos 0}\right\}=\exp \left\{\frac{-2}{9}\right\}=e^{-\frac{2}{9}}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the volumes of the bodies bounded by the surfaces.

$$
\frac{x^{2}}{3}+\frac{y^{2}}{16}=1, z=y \sqrt{3}, z=0(y \geq 0)
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

The base of the considered area is a semi-ellipse, in which

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x=0 \text { when } y=4 \\
& y=0 \text { when } x=\sqrt{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

That is, $x$ belongs to the interval $[-\sqrt{3}, \sqrt{3}]$, and $y \in [0,4]$

Consider the surface $z=y \sqrt{3}$:

$$
V_{z}=\int_{0}^{4} z d y=\int_{0}^{4} y \sqrt{3} d y=\sqrt{3} \int_{0}^{4} y d y=\left.\sqrt{3} \cdot \frac{y^{2}}{2}\right|_{0} ^{4}=\sqrt{3} \cdot \frac{16}{2}=8 \sqrt{3}
$$

Now consider the area of the base and find the volume of the given body:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{x^{2}}{3}+\frac{y^{2}}{16}=1 \\
& \frac{y^{2}}{16}=1-\frac{x^{2}}{3} \\
& V=8 \sqrt{3} \int_{-\sqrt{3}}^{\sqrt{3}}\left(1-\frac{x^{2}}{3}\right) d x=\left.8 \sqrt{3}\left(x-\frac{x^{3}}{9}\right)\right|_{-\sqrt{3}} ^{\sqrt{3}} d x=16 \sqrt{3}\left(\sqrt{3}-\frac{\sqrt{3}^{2}}{9}\right)=32
\end{aligned}
$$

Answer: $V=32$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the area of the figure bounded by the lines given by the equations.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=3(t-\sin t) \\
y=3(1-\cos t)
\end{array}\right. \\
& y=3(0<x<6 \pi, y \geq 3)
\end{aligned}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

Let's find the points of intersection:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y=3(1-\cos t)=3 \\
& 1-\cos t=1 \\
& \cos t=0 \\
& t=\frac{\pi}{2}+\pi n, n \in \mathbb{Z}
\end{aligned}
$$

We are interested in the interval \(0 < x < 6\pi\). Then the abscissas of the points of intersection will be:

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_fa23e2deef6f8d90c6d5g-17.jpg?height=1002&width=1014&top_left_y=1098&top_left_x=909)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& t=\frac{\pi}{2} \Rightarrow x=3\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\sin \frac{\pi}{2}\right)=\frac{3 \pi}{2}-3 \\
& t=\frac{3 \pi}{2} \Rightarrow x=3\left(\frac{3 \pi}{2}-\sin \frac{3 \pi}{2}\right)=\frac{9 \pi}{2}+3
\end{aligned}
$$

Calculate the area:

$$
S=\int_{\pi / 2}^{3 \pi / 2} 3(1-\cos t) \cdot(3(t-\sin t))' d t=
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =9 \cdot \int_{\pi / 2}^{3 \pi / 2}(1-\cos t) \cdot(1-\cos t) d t= \\
& =9 \cdot \int_{\pi / 2}^{3 \pi / 2}\left(1-2 \cos t+\cos ^{2} t\right) d t=\left.9 \cdot(t-2 \sin t)\right|_{\pi / 2} ^{3 \pi / 2}+9 \cdot \int_{\pi / 2}^{3 \pi / 2} \frac{1}{2}(1+\cos 2 t) d t= \\
& =9 \cdot\left(\frac{3 \pi}{2}-2 \sin \frac{3 \pi}{2}\right)-9\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-2 \sin \frac{\pi}{2}\right)+\left.\frac{9}{2} \cdot\left(t+\frac{1}{2} \sin 2 t\right)\right|_{\pi / 2} ^{3 \pi / 2}= \\
& =\frac{27 \pi}{2}+18-\frac{9 \pi}{2}+18+\frac{9}{2} \cdot\left(\frac{3 \pi}{2}+\frac{1}{2} \sin 3 \pi\right)-\frac{9}{2} \cdot\left(\frac{\pi}{2}+\frac{1}{2} \sin \pi\right)= \\
& =9 \pi+36+\frac{27 \pi}{4}+0-\frac{9 \pi}{4}-0=9 \pi+36+\frac{18 \pi}{4}=\frac{27 \pi}{2}+36
\end{aligned}
$$

Source — "http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\� \%D0\%9A\%D1\%83\%D0\%B7\%D0\%BD\%D0\%B5\%D1\%86\%D0\%BE\%D0\%B2_\%D0\%98\%D0\%BD $\% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 82 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 5 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 3 \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 80 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 0 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{BB} \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 8 \mathrm{~B}+15-9$ "

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by the equations in polar coordinates.

$$
\rho=1-\sin \varphi, -\frac{\pi}{2} \leq \varphi \leq -\frac{\pi}{6}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

The length of the arc of a curve given by an equation in polar coordinates is determined by the formula

$$
L=\int_{\phi_{1}}^{\phi_{2}} \sqrt{\rho^{2}+\left(\frac{d \rho}{d \phi}\right)^{2}} d \phi
$$

Let's find $\frac{d \rho}{d \phi}$:

$$
\frac{d \rho}{d \phi}=(-\cos \phi)
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
L & =\int_{-\pi / 2}^{-\pi / 6} \sqrt{(1-\sin \phi)^{2}+(-\cos \phi)^{2}} d \phi= \\
& =\int_{-\pi / 2}^{-\pi / 6} \sqrt{1-2 \sin \phi+\sin ^{2} \phi+\cos ^{2} \phi} d \phi= \\
& =\int_{-\pi / 2}^{-\pi / 6} \sqrt{2-2 \sin \phi} d \phi= \\
& =\int_{-\pi / 2}^{-\pi / 6} \sqrt{2-2 \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\phi\right)} d \phi= \\
& =\int_{-\pi / 2}^{-\pi / 6} \sqrt{4 \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{\phi}{2}\right)} d \phi= \\
& =\int_{-\pi / 2}^{-\pi / 6} 2 \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{\phi}{2}\right) d \phi=\left.4 \cdot \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{\phi}{2}\right)\right|_{-\pi / 2} ^{-\pi / 6}= \\
& =4\left(\cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{-\pi}{6}\right)-\cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{-\pi}{2}\right)\right)=4\left(\cos \left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right)-\cos \left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\right)=4\left(\frac{1}{2}-0\right)=2
\end{aligned}
$$

## Problem Statement

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by the equations in polar coordinates.

$$
\rho=4(1-\sin \varphi), 0 \leq \varphi \leq \frac{\pi}{6}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

The length of the arc of a curve given by an equation in polar coordinates is determined by the formula

$$
L=\int_{\phi_{1}}^{\phi_{2}} \sqrt{\rho^{2}+\left(\frac{d \rho}{d \phi}\right)^{2}} d \phi
$$

Let's find $\frac{d \rho}{d \phi}$:

$$
\frac{d \rho}{d \phi}=4(-\cos \phi)
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
L & =\int_{0}^{\pi / 6} \sqrt{16(1-\sin \phi)^{2}+16(-\cos \phi)^{2}} d \phi= \\
& =4 \int_{0}^{\pi / 6} \sqrt{1-2 \sin \phi+\sin ^{2} \phi+\cos ^{2} \phi} d \phi= \\
& =4 \int_{0}^{\pi / 6} \sqrt{2-2 \sin \phi} d \phi= \\
& =4 \int_{0}^{\pi / 6} \sqrt{2-2 \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\phi\right)} d \phi= \\
& =4 \int_{0}^{\pi / 6} \sqrt{4 \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{\phi}{2}\right)} d \phi= \\
& =4 \int_{0}^{\pi / 6} 2 \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{\phi}{2}\right) d \phi=\left.4 \cdot 4 \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{\phi}{2}\right)\right|_{0} ^{\pi / 6}= \\
& =16\left(\cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{\pi}{12}\right)-\cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4}-0\right)\right)=16\left(\cos \left(\frac{\pi}{6}\right)-\cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\right)=16\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right)=8(\sqrt{3}-\sqrt{2})
\end{aligned}
$$

## Problem Statement

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{-1}^{0}\left(x^{2}+4 x+3\right) \cos x d x
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\int_{-1}^{0}\left(x^{2}+4 x+3\right) \cos x d x=
$$

Let's denote:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u=x^{2}+4 x+3 ; d u=(2 x+4) d x \\
& d v=\cos x d x ; v=\sin x
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the integration by parts formula $\int u d v=u v-\int v d u$, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\left.\left(x^{2}+4 x+3\right) \sin x\right|_{-1} ^{0}-\int_{-1}^{0} \sin x(2 x+4) d x= \\
& =\left(0^{2}+4 \cdot 0+3\right) \sin 0-\left((-1)^{2}+4 \cdot(-1)+3\right) \sin (-1)-\int_{-1}^{0} \sin x(2 x+4) d x= \\
& =3 \cdot 0-(1-4+3) \sin (-1)-\int_{-1}^{0} \sin x(2 x+4) d x=-\int_{-1}^{0} \sin x(2 x+4) d x=
\end{aligned}
$$

Let's denote:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u=2 x+4 ; d u=2 d x \\
& d v=\sin x d x ; v=-\cos x
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the integration by parts formula $\int u d v=u v-\int v d u$, we get:

$$
=-\left(\left.(2 x+4) \cdot(-\cos x)\right|_{-1} ^{0}-\int_{-1}^{0}(-\cos x) \cdot 2 d x\right)=
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =-\left((2 \cdot 0+4) \cdot(-\cos 0)-(2 \cdot(-1)+4) \cdot(-\cos (-1))+2 \int_{-1}^{0} \cos x d x\right)= \\
& =-\left(-4+2 \cos (-1)+\left.2 \sin x\right|_{-1} ^{0}\right)=-(-4+2 \cos 1+2 \sin 0-2 \sin (-1))= \\
& =-(-4+2 \cos 1+2 \sin 1)=4-2 \cos 1-2 \sin 1
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the area of the figure bounded by the graphs of the functions:

$$
y=x^{2} \sqrt{8-x^{2}}, y=0, (0 \leq x \leq 2 \sqrt{2})
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

The desired area $S$ is:

$S=\int_{0}^{2 \sqrt{2}} x^{2} \sqrt{8-x^{2}} d x$

We will use a trigonometric substitution:

$\sqrt{8-x^{2}}=2 \sqrt{2} \sin t$, hence

$x=2 \sqrt{2} \cos t, d x=2 \sqrt{2} \sin t d t$

When $x=0=2 \sqrt{2} \cos t \Rightarrow t=\frac{\pi}{2}$

and when $x=1=2 \sqrt{2} \cos t \Rightarrow t=0$

Then we get

$S=\int_{0}^{2 \sqrt{2}} x^{2} \sqrt{8-x^{2}} d x$

Integrals 14-16

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_aa6951b1e92815ea34b6g-29.jpg?height=1422&width=788&top_left_y=1042&top_left_x=1139)

$=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2}(2 \sqrt{2} \cos t)^{2} \cdot \sqrt{8-(2 \sqrt{2} \cos t)^{2}} \cdot 2 \sqrt{2} \sin t d t=$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} 4 \cdot 2 \cos ^{2} t \cdot \sqrt{8-4 \cdot 2 \cos ^{2} t} \cdot 2 \sqrt{2} \sin t d t= \\
& =16 \sqrt{2} \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \cos ^{2} t \cdot 2 \sqrt{2} \cdot \sqrt{1-\cos ^{2} t} \cdot \sin t d t= \\
& =64 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \cos ^{2} t \cdot \sin ^{2} t d t= \\
& =\frac{64}{4} \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \sin ^{2} 2 t d t= \\
& =\frac{16}{2} \int_{0}^{\pi / 2}(1-\cos 4 t) d t= \\
& =\left.(8 t-2 \sin 4 t)\right|_{0} ^{\pi / 2}=8 \cdot \frac{\pi}{2}-2 \cdot \sin \frac{4 \pi}{2}=4 \pi-0=4 \pi
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Calculate the area of the figure bounded by the graphs of the functions:

$$
x=\sqrt{e^{y}-1}, x=0, y=\ln 2
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

## Integrals 14-17

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_aa6951b1e92815ea34b6g-31.jpg?height=1153&width=1105&top_left_y=1031&top_left_x=790)

$$
x=\sqrt{e^{y}-1} \Rightarrow y=\ln \left(x^{2}+1\right)
$$

Let's find the limits of integration:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x_{1}=0 \text { - given in the problem statement } \\
& x_{2}=\sqrt{e^{y}-1} ; y=\ln 2 ; \Rightarrow x_{2}=\sqrt{e^{\ln 2}-1}=\sqrt{2-1}=1
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& S=\int_{0}^{1}\left(\ln 2-\ln \left(x^{2}+1\right)\right) d x= \\
& =\int_{0}^{1} \ln 2 d x-\int_{0}^{1} \ln \left(x^{2}+1\right) d x= \\
& =\ln 2 \cdot \int_{0}^{1} d x-\int_{0}^{1} \ln \left(x^{2}+1\right) d x= \\
& =\left.\ln 2 \cdot x\right|_{0} ^{1}-\int_{0}^{1} \ln \left(x^{2}+1\right) d x= \\
& =\ln 2 \cdot(1-0)-\int_{0}^{1} \ln \left(x^{2}+1\right) d x= \\
& =\ln 2-\int_{0}^{1} \ln \left(x^{2}+1\right) d x=\ln 2-S_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

To compute the second integral, we use integration by parts:

$\int_{a}^{b} u d v=\left.u \cdot v\right|_{a} ^{b}-\int_{a}^{b} v d u$

Where

$$
u=\ln \left(x^{2}+1\right) ; d u=\frac{2 x}{x^{2}+1} ; v=x ; d v=d x
$$

Then we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& S_{2}=\int_{0}^{1} \ln \left(x^{2}+1\right) d x= \\
& =\left.x \cdot \ln \left(x^{2}+1\right)\right|_{0} ^{1}-\int_{0}^{1} x \cdot \frac{2 x}{x^{2}+1} d x= \\
& =1 \cdot \ln 2-0 \cdot \ln 1-2 \int_{0}^{1} \frac{x^{2}+1-1}{x^{2}+1} d x= \\
& =\ln 2-2 \int_{0}^{1}\left(1-\frac{1}{x^{2}+1}\right) d x= \\
& =\ln 2-2 \int_{0}^{1} d x+2 \int_{0}^{1} \frac{1}{x^{2}+1} d x= \\
& =\ln 2-\left.2 \cdot x\right|_{0} ^{1}+\left.2 \cdot \operatorname{arctg} x\right|_{0} ^{1}= \\
& =\ln 2-2 \cdot(1-0)+2(\operatorname{arctg} 1-\operatorname{arctg} 0)= \\
& =\ln 2-2+2\left(\frac{\pi}{4}-0\right)=\ln 2-2+\frac{\pi}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

In the end:

$$
S=\ln 2-\left(\ln 2-2+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)=2-\frac{\pi}{2} \approx 0.429
$$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Calculate the area of the figure bounded by the graphs of the functions:

$$
x=(y-2)^{3}, x=4 y-8
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (y-2)^{3}=4(y-2) \\
& (y-2)\left[4-(y-2)^{2}\right]=0 \\
& \begin{array}{l}
4-y^{2}+4 y-4=0 \\
y(y-4)=0
\end{array} \\
& \frac{S}{2}=\int_{2}^{4}(4 y-8) d y-\int_{2}^{4}(y-3)^{3} d y= \\
& =\left.2 y^{2}\right|_{4} ^{2}-\left.8 y\right|_{4} ^{2}-\int_{2}^{4}\left(y^{3}-6 y^{2}+12 y-8\right) d y= \\
& =32-8-32+16-\left(\left.\frac{y^{4}}{4}\right|_{4} ^{2}-\left.6 \frac{y^{3}}{3}\right|_{4} ^{2}+\left.6 y^{2}\right|_{4} ^{2}-\left.8 y\right|_{4} ^{2}\right)= \\
& =8-\left(\frac{256}{4}-4-128+16+96-24-32+16\right)=4 \\
& S=2 \cdot \frac{S}{2}=8
\end{aligned}
$$

## Problem Kuznetsov Integrals 14-22

## Material from Plusi

llm_response:
This problem involves calculating the area bounded by two curves. The solution requires setting up the integral expressions based on the intersection points, followed by evaluating these integrals to find the area. It mainly focuses on computations related to integration and is therefore not simply a direct derivative computation.

Given the nature of the problem, it requires multiple steps of computation to derive the final area. Therefore, it is classified as medium.

**Classification**: MEDIUM

original.solution:
## Solution

The length of the arc of a curve defined by parametric equations is determined by the formula

$$
L=\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \sqrt{\left(x^{\prime}(t)\right)^{2}+\left(y^{\prime}(t)\right)^{2}} d t
$$

Let's find the derivatives with respect to $t$ for the given curve:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x=\left(t^{2}-2\right) \sin t+2 t \cos t \\
& x^{\prime}(t)=2 t \sin t+\left(t^{2}-2\right) \cos t+2 \cos t-2 t \sin t=2 t \sin t+t^{2} \cos t-2 \cos t+2 \cos t-2 t \sin t=t^{2} \cos t \\
& y=\left(2-t^{2}\right) \cos t+2 t \sin t \\
& y^{\prime}(t)=-2 t \cos t-\left(2-t^{2}\right) \sin t+2 \sin t+2 t \cos t=-2 t \cos t-2 \sin t+t^{2} \sin t+2 \sin t+2 t \cos t=t^{2} \sin t
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, using the formula above, we have:

$$
\begin{aligned}
L & =\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \sqrt{\left(t^{2} \cos t\right)^{2}+\left(t^{2} \sin t\right)^{2}} d t= \\
& =\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \sqrt{t^{4}\left(\cos ^{2} t+\sin ^{2} t\right)} d t=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \sqrt{t^{4} \cdot 1} d t=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} t^{2} d t=\left.\frac{1}{3} \cdot t^{3}\right|_{0} ^{\pi / 2}= \\
& =\frac{1}{3} \cdot\left(\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)^{3}-0^{3}\right)=\frac{\pi^{3}}{24}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Task Condition

Calculate the volumes of solids formed by rotating figures bounded by the graphs of functions. The axis of rotation is $O y$.

$$
y=x^{2}, x=2, y=0
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

Since the $O y$ axis is the axis of rotation, the volume is found using the formula:

$$
V=\pi \cdot \int_{a}^{b} x^{2} d y
$$

Express $x$ in terms of $y$ and find the limits of integration:

$$
y=x^{2} \Rightarrow x=\sqrt{y}
$$

From the problem statement, we already have: $y_{1}=0$.

Now find the upper limit:

$$
y=x^{2} ; x=2 \Rightarrow y_{2}=2^{2}=4
$$

Find the volume of the solid as the difference of the volumes of two solids of revolution:
Integrals 21-19

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_cfec74fe4e2360126fc5g-38.jpg?height=1345&width=948&top_left_y=1092&top_left_x=1002)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& V=\pi \cdot \int_{0}^{4}(2)^{2} d y-\pi \cdot \int_{0}^{4}(\sqrt{y})^{2} d y=\pi \cdot \int_{0}^{4}(4-y) d y= \\
& =\left.\pi \cdot\left(4 y-\frac{y^{2}}{2}\right)\right|_{0} ^{4}=\pi \cdot((16-8)-(0-0))=8 \pi
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt{n+2}-\sqrt{n^{2}+2}}{\sqrt[4]{4 n^{4}+1}-\sqrt[3]{n^{4}-1}}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt{n+2}-\sqrt{n^{2}+2}}{\sqrt[4]{4 n^{4}+1}-\sqrt[3]{n^{1}-1}}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\frac{1}{n}\left(\sqrt{n+2}-\sqrt{n^{2}+2}\right)}{\frac{1}{n}\left(\sqrt[4]{4 n^{\frac{1}{4}+1}}-\sqrt[3]{n^{4}-1}\right)}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt{\frac{1}{n}+\frac{2}{n^{2}}}-\sqrt{1+\frac{2}{n^{2}}}}{\sqrt{4+\frac{1}{n^{4}}}-\sqrt[3]{n-\frac{1}{n^{3}}}}=\left\{\frac{\sqrt{0+0}-\sqrt{1+0}}{\sqrt[4]{4+0}-\sqrt[3]{\infty-0}}=\frac{-1}{-\infty}\right\}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{0}^{\arccos \sqrt{2 / 3}} \frac{\tan x + 2}{\sin^2 x + 2 \cos^2 x - 3} \, dx
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{0}^{\arccos \sqrt{2 / 3}} \frac{\operatorname{tg} x+2}{\sin ^{2} x+2 \cos ^{2} x-3} d x=\int_{0}^{\arccos \sqrt{2 / 3}} \frac{\operatorname{tg} x+2}{\cos ^{2} x-2} d x= \\
& =\int_{0}^{\arccos \sqrt{2 / 3}} \frac{\operatorname{tg} x+2}{\frac{1}{2} \cdot \cos 2 x-\frac{3}{2}} d x=2 \cdot \int_{0}^{\arccos \sqrt{2 / 3}} \frac{\operatorname{tg} x+2}{\cos 2 x-3} d x=
\end{aligned}
$$

We will use the substitution:

$$
t=\operatorname{tg} x
$$

From which:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \cos 2 x=\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}, d x=\frac{d t}{1+t^{2}} \\
& x=0 \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg} 0=0 \\
& x=\arccos \sqrt{2 / 3} \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg}(\arccos \sqrt{2 / 3})=\sqrt{\frac{1}{\cos ^{2}(\arccos \sqrt{2 / 3})}-1}= \\
& =\sqrt{\frac{1}{\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)}-1}=\sqrt{\frac{3}{2}-1}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Substitute:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =2 \cdot \int_{0}^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} \frac{t+2}{\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}-3} \cdot \frac{d t}{1+t^{2}}=2 \cdot \int_{0}^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} \frac{t+2}{1-t^{2}-3-3 t^{2}} d t=2 \cdot \int_{0}^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} \frac{t+2}{-2-4 t^{2}} d t= \\
& =-\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} \frac{t+2}{1+2 t^{2}} d t=-\frac{1}{4} \cdot \int_{0}^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} \frac{4 t}{2 t^{2}+1} d t-\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} \frac{1}{t^{2}+\frac{1}{2}} d t=
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =-\frac{1}{4} \cdot \int_{0}^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} \frac{d\left(2 t^{2}+1\right)}{2 t^{2}+1} d t-\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} \frac{1}{t^{2}+\frac{1}{2}} d t=\left.\left(-\frac{1}{4} \cdot \ln \left(2 t^{2}+1\right)-\frac{1}{\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}}} \cdot \operatorname{arctg} \frac{t}{\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}}}\right)\right|_{0} ^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}= \\
& =\left.\left(-\frac{1}{4} \cdot \ln \left(2 t^{2}+1\right)-\sqrt{2} \cdot \operatorname{arctg} \sqrt{2} t\right)\right|_{0} ^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}= \\
& =\left(-\frac{1}{4} \cdot \ln \left(2\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^{2}+1\right)-\sqrt{2} \cdot \operatorname{arctg}\left(\sqrt{2} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\right)- \\
& -\left(-\frac{1}{4} \cdot \ln \left(2 \cdot 0^{2}+1\right)-\sqrt{2} \cdot \operatorname{arctg}(\sqrt{2} \cdot 0)\right)= \\
& =-\frac{1}{4} \cdot \ln 2-\sqrt{2} \cdot \operatorname{arctg} 1+\frac{1}{4} \cdot \ln 1+\sqrt{2} \cdot \operatorname{arctg} 0= \\
& =-\frac{\ln 2}{4}-\sqrt{2} \cdot \frac{\pi}{4}=-\frac{\ln 2+\sqrt{2} \pi}{4}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{0}^{\arcsin \sqrt{7 / 8}} \frac{6 \sin ^{2} x}{4+3 \cos 2 x} d x
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

We will use the substitution:

$$
t=\operatorname{tg} x
$$

From which:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sin ^{2} x=\frac{t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}, \cos 2 x=\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}, d x=\frac{d t}{1+t^{2}} \\
& x=0 \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg} 0=0 \\
& x=\arcsin \sqrt{\frac{7}{8}} \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg}\left(\arcsin \sqrt{\frac{7}{8}}\right)=\sqrt{\frac{1}{1-\sin ^{2}\left(\arcsin \sqrt{\frac{7}{8}}\right)}-1}= \\
& =\sqrt{\frac{1}{1-\frac{7}{8}}-1}=\sqrt{8-1}=\sqrt{7}
\end{aligned}
$$

Substitute:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\arcsin \sqrt{7 / 8} & \frac{6 \sin ^{2} x}{4+3 \cos 2 x} d x=\int_{0}^{\sqrt{7}} \frac{\frac{6 t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}}{4+3 \cdot \frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}} \cdot \frac{d t}{1+t^{2}}= \\
= & \int_{0}^{\sqrt{7}} \frac{6 t^{2}}{4+4 t^{2}+3-3 t^{2}} \cdot \frac{d t}{1+t^{2}}=\int_{0}^{\sqrt{7}} \frac{6 t^{2}}{\left(t^{2}+7\right)\left(1+t^{2}\right)} d t=
\end{aligned}
$$

Decompose the proper rational fraction into elementary fractions using the method of undetermined coefficients:

$$
\frac{6 t^{2}}{\left(t^{2}+7\right)\left(1+t^{2}\right)}=\frac{A t+B}{7+t^{2}}+\frac{C t+D}{1+t^{2}}=
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{(A t+B) \cdot\left(1+t^{2}\right)+(C t+D) \cdot\left(7+t^{2}\right)}{\left(7+t^{2}\right)\left(1+t^{2}\right)}= \\
& =\frac{A t+A t^{3}+B+B t^{2}+7 C t+C t^{3}+7 D+D t^{2}}{\left(7+t^{2}\right)\left(1+t^{2}\right)}= \\
& =\frac{(A+C) t^{3}+(B+D) t^{2}+(A+7 C) t+(B+7 D)}{\left(1+t^{2}\right)\left(1+7 t^{2}\right)} \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
A+C=0 \\
B+D=6 \\
A+7 C=0 \\
B+7 D=0
\end{array}\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
A=-C \\
-7 D+D=6 \\
-C+7 C=0 \\
B=-7 D
\end{array}\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
A=-C \\
-6 D=6 \\
C=0 \\
B=-7 D
\end{array}\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
A=0 \\
D=-1 \\
C=0 \\
B=7
\end{array}\right. \\
& \frac{6 t^{2}}{\left(t^{2}+7\right)\left(1+t^{2}\right)}=\frac{7}{7+t^{2}}-\frac{1}{1+t^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\int_{0}^{\sqrt{7}}\left(\frac{7}{7+t^{2}}-\frac{1}{1+t^{2}}\right) d t=\left.\frac{7}{\sqrt{7}} \cdot \operatorname{arctg} \frac{t}{\sqrt{7}}\right|_{0} ^{\sqrt{7}}-\left.\operatorname{arctg} t\right|_{0} ^{\sqrt{7}}= \\
& =\sqrt{7} \cdot \operatorname{arctg} \frac{\sqrt{7}}{\sqrt{7}}-\sqrt{7} \cdot \operatorname{arctg} \frac{0}{\sqrt{7}}-\operatorname{arctg} \sqrt{7}+\operatorname{arctg} 0= \\
& =\sqrt{7} \cdot \operatorname{arctg} 1-0-\operatorname{arctg} \sqrt{7}+0=\frac{\sqrt{7} \pi}{4}-\operatorname{arctg} \sqrt{7}
\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{0}^{\arcsin (3 / \sqrt{10})} \frac{2 \tan x-5}{(4 \cos x-\sin x)^{2}} d x
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \arcsin (3 / \sqrt{10}) \quad \arcsin (3 / \sqrt{10}) \\
& \int_{0} \frac{2 \operatorname{tg} x-5}{(4 \cos x-\sin x)^{2}} d x=\quad \int_{0} \frac{2 \operatorname{tg} x-5}{16 \cos ^{2} x-8 \cos x \sin x+\sin ^{2} x} d x= \\
& \arcsin (3 / \sqrt{10}) \\
& =\int_{0} \frac{2 \operatorname{tg} x-5}{15 \cos ^{2} x-4 \sin 2 x+1} d x=
\end{aligned}
$$

We will use the substitution:

$$
t=\operatorname{tg} x
$$

From which:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sin 2 x=\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}}, \cos ^{2} x=\frac{1}{1+t^{2}}, d x=\frac{d t}{1+t^{2}} \\
& x=0 \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg} 0=0 \\
& x=\arcsin \frac{3}{\sqrt{10}} \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg}\left(\arcsin \frac{3}{\sqrt{10}}\right)=\sqrt{\frac{1}{1-\sin ^{2}\left(\arcsin \frac{3}{\sqrt{10}}\right)}-1}= \\
& =\sqrt{\frac{1}{1-\frac{9}{10}}-1}=\sqrt{10-1}=\sqrt{9}=3
\end{aligned}
$$

Substitute:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\int_{0}^{3} \frac{2 t-5}{\frac{15}{1+t^{2}}-\frac{8 t}{1+t^{2}}+1} \cdot \frac{d t}{1+t^{2}}=\int_{0}^{3} \frac{2 t-5}{15-8 t+1+t^{2}} d t= \\
& =\int_{0}^{3} \frac{2 t-8+3}{(t-4)^{2}} d t=2 \cdot \int_{0}^{3} \frac{1}{t-4} d t+3 \cdot \int_{0}^{3} \frac{1}{(t-4)^{2}} d t= \\
& =2 \ln \left|t-4 \|_{0}^{3}-\frac{3}{t-4}\right|_{0}^{3}=2 \ln |3-4|-2 \ln |0-4|-\frac{3}{3-4}+\frac{3}{0-4}=
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
=2 \ln 1-2 \ln 4+3-\frac{3}{4}=0-4 \ln 2+\frac{9}{4}=\frac{9}{4}-\ln 16
$$

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{\pi / 4}^{\arccos (1 / \sqrt{26})} \frac{d x}{(6-\operatorname{tg} x) \sin 2 x}
$$
original.solution:
## Solution

Let's use the substitution:

$$
t=\operatorname{tg} x
$$

From which:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sin 2 x=\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}}, d x=\frac{d t}{1+t^{2}} \\
& x=\frac{\pi}{4} \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg} \frac{\pi}{4}=1 \\
& x=\arccos \frac{1}{\sqrt{26}} \Rightarrow t=\operatorname{tg}\left(\arccos \frac{1}{\sqrt{26}}\right)=\sqrt{\frac{1}{\cos ^{2}\left(\arccos \frac{1}{\sqrt{26}}\right)}-1}= \\
& =\sqrt{\frac{1}{\left(\frac{1}{26}\right)}-1}=\sqrt{26-1}=\sqrt{25}=5
\end{aligned}
$$

Substitute:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\pi / 4}^{\arccos (1 / \sqrt{26})} \frac{d x}{(6-\operatorname{tg} x) \sin 2 x}=\int_{1}^{5} \frac{1}{(6-t) \cdot \frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}}} \cdot \frac{d t}{1+t^{2}}= \\
& =\int_{1}^{5} \frac{1}{2 t(6-t)} d t=-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int_{1}^{5} \frac{1}{t(t-6)} d t=
\end{aligned}
$$

Decompose the proper rational fraction into partial fractions using the method of undetermined coefficients:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{t(t-6)}=\frac{A}{t}+\frac{B}{t-6}=\frac{A(t-6)+B t}{t(t-6)}=\frac{(A+B) t-6 A}{t(t-6)} \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
A+B=0 \\
-6 A=1
\end{array}\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
B=\frac{1}{6} \\
A=-\frac{1}{6}
\end{array}\right. \\
& \frac{1}{t(t-6)}=-\frac{1}{6 t}+\frac{1}{6(t-6)}
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int_{1}^{5}\left(-\frac{1}{6 t}+\frac{1}{6(t-6)}\right) d t=\frac{1}{12} \cdot \int_{1}^{5}\left(\frac{1}{t}-\frac{1}{t-6}\right) d t= \\
& =\left.\frac{1}{12} \cdot(\ln |t|-\ln |t-6|)\right|_{1} ^{5}=\frac{1}{12} \cdot(\ln |5|-\ln |5-6|)-\frac{1}{12} \cdot(\ln |1|-\ln |1-6|)= \\
& =\frac{1}{12} \cdot(\ln 5-\ln 1)-\frac{1}{12} \cdot(\ln 1-\ln 5)=\frac{1}{12} \cdot \ln 5+\frac{1}{12} \cdot \ln 5=\frac{\ln 5}{6}
\end{aligned}
$$

Source — «http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\� \%D0\%9A\%D1\%83\%D0\%B7\%D0\%BD\%D0\%B5\%D1\%86\%D0\%BE\%D0\%B2_\%D0\%98\%D0\%BD $\% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 82 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 5 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 3 \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 80 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 0 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{BB} \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 8 \mathrm{~B} \_9-25$ » Categories: Kuznetsov's Problem Book Integrals Problem 9 | Integrals

original.problem:
## Problem Statement

Derive the equations of the tangent and normal lines to the curve at the point corresponding to the parameter value $t=t_{0}$.

\[
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=\arcsin \frac{t}{\sqrt{1+t^{2}}} \\
y=\arccos \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+t^{2}}}
\end{array}\right.
\]

$t_{0}=-1$
original.solution:
## Solution

Since $t_{0}=-1$, then

$x_{0}=\arcsin \frac{-1}{\sqrt{1+(-1)^{2}}}=\arcsin \frac{-1}{\sqrt{2}}=-\frac{\pi}{4}$
$y_{0}=\arccos \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+(-1)^{2}}}=\arccos \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}=\frac{\pi}{4}$

Find the derivatives:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x_{t}^{\prime}=\left(\arcsin \frac{t}{\sqrt{1+t^{2}}}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{t}{\sqrt{1+t^{2}}}\right)^{2}}} \cdot \frac{1 \cdot \sqrt{1+t^{2}}-t \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{1+t^{2}}} \cdot 2 t}{1+t^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{\sqrt{1+t^{2}}}{1+t^{2}-t^{2}} \cdot \frac{1+t^{2}-t^{2}}{\left(1+t^{2}\right) \cdot \sqrt{1+t^{2}}}=\frac{1}{1+t^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y_{t}^{\prime}=\left(\arccos \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+t^{2}}}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+t^{2}}}\right)^{2}}} \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{1+t^{2}}} \cdot 2 t= \\
& =\frac{\sqrt{1+t^{2}}}{\sqrt{1+t^{2}-1}} \cdot \frac{t}{\sqrt{1+t^{2}}}=\frac{t}{\sqrt{t^{2}}}=1 \\
& y_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{y_{t}^{\prime}}{x_{t}^{\prime}}=\frac{1}{\left(\frac{1}{1+t^{2}}\right)}=1+t^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then:

$y_{0}^{\prime}=1+(-1)^{2}=2$

Equation of the tangent line:

$y-y_{0}=y_{0}^{\prime}\left(x-x_{0}\right)$

$y-\frac{\pi}{4}=2 \cdot\left(x-\left(-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\right)$

$y=2 x+\frac{\pi}{2}+\frac{\pi}{4}$

$y=2 x+\frac{3 \pi}{4}$

Equation of the normal line:

$y-y_{0}=-\frac{1}{y_{0}^{\prime}}\left(x-x_{0}\right)$

$y-\frac{\pi}{4}=-\frac{1}{2}\left(x-\left(-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\right)$

$y=-\frac{x}{2}-\frac{\pi}{8}+\frac{\pi}{4}$

$y=-\frac{x}{2}+\frac{\pi}{8}$

original.problem:
Compute $\int_{0}^{\pi / 2}\left(\sin ^{2}(\sin x)+\cos ^{2}(\cos x)\right) d x$.

#
original.solution:
Transform the integrand using the reduction formula $\sin x=\cos (\pi / 2-x)$ and the fundamental trigonometric identity $\sin ^{2} x+\cos ^{2} x=1$.

## Solution

Let's write: $\int_{0}^{\pi / 2}\left(\sin ^{2}(\sin x)+\cos ^{2}(\cos x)\right) d x=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2}\left(\sin ^{2}(\sin x)+1-\sin ^{2}(\sin (\pi / 2-x)) d x\right.$. But $\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} f(x) d x=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} f(\pi / 2-x) d x$, since the graphs of the functions $f(x)$ and $f(\pi / 2-x)$ are symmetric with respect to the line $x=\pi / 4$, and the integrals of these functions over the interval from 0 to $\pi / 2$ will be equal. Thus, the desired integral is $\pi / 2$.

## Answer

$\pi / 2$.

original.solution:
16. Let the function $f(x)=p x-\frac{p}{x}-2 \ln x$.
(1) If $f(x)$ is a monotonically increasing function in its domain, find the range of the real number $p$;
(2) Let $g(x)=\frac{2 e}{x}$, and $p>0$, if there exists at least one point $x_{0}$ in $[1, e]$ such that $f\left(x_{0}\right)>g\left(x_{0}\right)$, find the range of the real number $p$;
(3) Prove that for any positive integer $n$, $\sum_{k=1}^{n} \ln ^{2}\left(1+\frac{2}{k}\right) < 3$.
{3} Let $g(x)=2 \ln x-x+\frac{1}{x}$, then from (1) we know that $g(x)$ is a monotonically decreasing function in $(0,+\infty)$.

Since $g(1)=0$, for $x>1$, we have $g(x)<0$, i.e., $0<2 \ln x<x-\frac{1}{x}$.
Therefore, $2 \ln \sqrt{1+\frac{2}{k}}<\sqrt{1+\frac{2}{k}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\frac{2}{k}}}=\frac{2}{\sqrt{k(k+2)}}$,
i.e., $\ln \left(1+\frac{2}{k}\right)<\frac{2}{\sqrt{k(k+2)}}$
Thus, $\ln ^{2}\left(1+\frac{2}{k}\right)<\frac{4}{k(k+2)}$
Hence, $\sum_{k=1}^{n} \ln ^{2}\left(1+\frac{2}{k}\right)<\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{4}{k(k+2)}=2 \sum_{k=1}^{n}\left(\frac{1}{k}-\frac{1}{k+2}\right)$
$=2\left(1+\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{n+1}-\frac{1}{n+2}\right)<3$.
.20 points

(1) Given $f(x)=p x-\frac{p}{x}-2 \ln x$, we have $f^{\prime}(x)=p+\frac{p}{x^{2}}-\frac{2}{x}$.
To make $f(x)$ a monotonically increasing function in its domain $(0,+\infty)$, we need $f^{\prime}(x) \geq 0$,
i.e., $p x^{2}-2 x+p \geq 0$ holds for all $x \in (0,+\infty)$.
Thus, $p \geq \frac{2 x}{x^{2}+1}$. Note that: $\frac{2 x}{x^{2}+1} \leq \frac{2 x}{2 x}=1$, with equality when $x=1$,
i.e., $\frac{2 x}{x^{2}+1}$ reaches its maximum value of 1 at $x=1$.
Therefore, $p \geq 1$.
5 points
(2) Solution 1: Note that $g(x)=\frac{2 e}{x}$ is a decreasing function on $[1, e]$,
so $g(x)_{\min }=g(e)=2, g(x)_{\max }=g(1)=2 e$, i.e., $g(x) \in[2,2 e]$.
When $0 < p \leq 1$, $f(x)$ is a decreasing function on $[1, e]$, and $f(x)_{\min }=f(e)=p\left(e-\frac{1}{e}\right)-2 \ln e \leq 2$, which does not satisfy the condition.
When $p > 1$, $f(x)$ is an increasing function on $[1, e]$, and we need $f(x)_{\max }=f(e)=p\left(e-\frac{1}{e}\right)-2 \ln e > 2$, solving this gives $p>\frac{4 e}{e^{2}-1}$.
In summary, the range of $p$ is $\left(\frac{4 e}{e^{2}-1},+\infty\right)$.

Solution 2: The original proposition is equivalent to $f(x)-g(x)>0$ having a solution on $[1, e]$,
Let $F(x)=f(x)-g(x)=p x-\frac{p}{x}-2 \ln x-\frac{2 e}{x}$.
Since $F^{\prime}(x)=p+\frac{p}{x^{2}}-\frac{2}{x}+\frac{2 e}{x^{2}}=\frac{p x^{2}+p+2(e-x)}{x^{2}}>0$,
$F(x)$ is an increasing function,
Thus, $F(x)_{\max }=F(e)>0$, solving this gives $p>\frac{4 e}{e^{2}-1}$.
Therefore, the range of $p$ is $\left(\frac{4 e}{e^{2}-1},+\infty\right)$.

15 (1) Since $g^{\prime}(x)=f^{\prime}(x)-2 a x=\left(\mathrm{e}^{x}-1\right)-2 a x$.
Because the derivative $g^{\prime}(x)$ is an increasing function on $[0,+\infty)$, we have $\left[g^{\prime}(x)\right]^{\prime}=\mathrm{e}^{x}-2 a \geqslant 0$, thus $a \leqslant \frac{1}{2} \mathrm{e}^{x}, x \in[0,+\infty)$, so $a \leqslant \frac{1}{2}$, which means the maximum value of $a$ is $\frac{1}{2}$.
(2) From (1), we know $g^{\prime}(0)=0$, and when $a=\frac{1}{2}$, $g^{\prime}(x)$ is an increasing function on $[0,+\infty)$, hence $g^{\prime}(x) \geqslant g^{\prime}(0)=0$, so $g(x)$ is an increasing function on $[0,+\infty)$, and $g(0)=0$, i.e., $f(x) \geqslant \frac{1}{2} x^{2}+1$, where $x \in[0,+\infty)$.
By setting $x=\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{3}, \frac{1}{4}, \cdots, \frac{1}{n+1}$, we get
$$
\begin{array}{c}
f\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) \geqslant \frac{1}{2} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}+1, \\
f\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) \geqslant \frac{1}{2} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{2}+1, \\
\cdots \\
f\left(\frac{1}{n+1}\right) \geqslant \frac{1}{2} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{n+1}\right)^{2}+1 .
\end{array}
$$

Adding the above inequalities, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
& f\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)+f\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)+\cdots+f\left(\frac{1}{n+1}\right) \\
\geqslant & \frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{2}+\cdots+\left(\frac{1}{n+1}\right)^{2}\right]+n \\
> & \frac{1}{2}\left[\frac{1}{2 \times 3}+\frac{1}{3 \times 4}+\cdots+\frac{1}{(n+1)(n+2)}\right]+n \\
= & \frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{3}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{4}\right)+\cdots+\left(\frac{1}{n+1}-\frac{1}{n+2}\right)\right]+n \\
= & \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{n+2}\right)+n=n\left[1+\frac{1}{4(n+2)}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

【Solution】Solution: Let the original number of roosters be $x$, then the number of hens is $6x$. According to the problem, we can set up the equation:
$$
\begin{array}{l} 
6 x+60=4(x+60), \\
6 x+60=4 x+240, \\
6 x-4 x=240-60, \\
2 x=180, \\
x=90 ; \\
90+90 \times 6=630 \text{ (chickens); }
\end{array}
$$

Answer: The chicken farm originally raised a total of 630 chickens.
Therefore, the answer is: 630.

original.problem: 11. If $a, b$ are real numbers, $a<b$, the difference between the maximum and minimum values of the function $y=\sin x$ on the closed interval $[a, b]$ is 1, find the range of $b-a$.
original.solution: As shown in the figure, if $b-a>\pi$, then there exists a local extremum point $c$ and a zero point $d$ of $\sin x$ within $(a, b)$. Taking a sufficiently small positive number $\varepsilon$, such that the interval $[d-\varepsilon, d+\varepsilon] \subseteq(a, b)$, at this time $\sin (d-\varepsilon)$ and $\sin (d+\varepsilon)$ have opposite signs, thus there exists $d_{1} \in[d-\varepsilon, d+\varepsilon]$, such that $\sin d_{1}$ and $\sin c$ have opposite signs, hence $\left|\sin c-\sin d_{1}\right|>|\sin c|=1$, which is a contradiction; if $b-a<\frac{\pi}{3}$, then the maximum and minimum points of $\sin x$ on $[a, b]$ must be the two endpoints $c$ and $d$ of a monotonic interval $[c, d]$ with a length less than $\frac{\pi}{3}$, and $|\sin c-\sin d|=\left|2 \cos \frac{c+d}{2} \sin \frac{c-d}{2}\right| \leqslant 2\left|\sin \frac{c-d}{2}\right|<2 \sin \frac{\pi}{6}=1$, which is a contradiction. On the other hand, let $a=0, b=b_{0} \in\left[\frac{\pi}{2}, \pi\right]$, then the maximum value of $\sin x$ on $[a, b]$ is 1, and the minimum value is 0, which meets the requirement, at this time $b-a$ can take any value in $\left[\frac{\pi}{2}, \pi\right]$; also let $a=\arcsin (t-1), b=\arcsin t, t \in\left[\frac{1}{2}, 1\right]$, then the maximum value of $\sin x$ on $[a, b]$ is $t$, and the minimum value is $t-1$, which meets the requirement, when $t=\frac{1}{2}$, $b-a=\frac{\pi}{3}$; when $t=1$, $b-a=\frac{\pi}{2}$. The function $b-a=\arcsin t-\arcsin (t-1), t \in\left[\frac{1}{2}, 1\right]$ is a continuous function, thus $b-a$ can take any value in $\left[\frac{\pi}{2}, \pi\right]$. In summary, the range of $b-a$ is $\left[\frac{\pi}{2}, \pi\right] \cup\left[\frac{\pi}{2}, \pi\right]=\left[\frac{\pi}{3}, \pi\right]$.

original.problem: The cost of the iron plate used for the bottom is 40 yuan per square meter, and the cost of the iron plate used for the sides is 32 yuan per square meter. If we ignore the loss in production, what should the radius of the base and the height of the oil tank be to minimize the material cost of making the oil tank?
original.solution:
Let the radius of the base of a cylindrical oil tank be $r \mathrm{~m}$, the height be $h \mathrm{~m}$, and the cost be $y$ yuan. According to the problem, we have $\pi r^{2} h=20 \pi$, so $h=\frac{20}{r^{2}}$. Therefore,
$$
\begin{aligned}
y & =2 \pi r^{2} \cdot 40+2 \pi r h \cdot 32=80 \pi r^{2}+64 \pi r h=80 \pi r^{2}+64 \pi r \cdot \frac{20}{r^{2}} \\
& =80 \pi r^{2}+\frac{1280 \pi}{r}=80 \pi r^{2}+\frac{640 \pi}{r}+\frac{640 \pi}{r} \\
& \geqslant 3 \sqrt[3]{80 \pi r^{2} \cdot \frac{640 \pi}{r} \cdot \frac{640 \pi}{r}}=960 \pi(\text { yuan }) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Equality holds if and only if $80 \pi r^{2}=\frac{640 \pi}{r}$, i.e., $r=2, h=5$.
Answer: When the radius of the base of the oil tank is $2 \mathrm{~m}$ and the height is $5 \mathrm{~m}$, the material cost is minimized.

llm_response:
This problem is primarily focused on optimizing the dimensions of a cylindrical oil tank to minimize material costs. It involves setting up a cost function based on given geometric relationships and constraints, then finding the minimum of that cost function. 

The solution also engages with principles of optimization and includes reasoning about equalities in a context that suggests the use of inequalities (like AM-GM inequality) to establish optimal points.

Thus, the problem does not solely involve straightforward computations but rather requires formulating and solving an optimization problem. This more complex nature elevates it from a simple computation to a medium-level problem requiring synthesis of information and understanding of optimization principles.

Classification: MEDIUM

However, it still seems odd that we are given a sum of three ranges. So we look for a substitution that might bring the ranges into coincidence or something like it. A little tinkering suggests y = 1/(1-x). This takes (1/101, 1/11) to (101/100, 11/10), and (101/100, 11/10) to (-100, -10). We also find that it takes (x 2 - x)/(x 3 - 3x + 1) to (y 2 - y)/(y 3 - 3y + 1). Let I(a, b) = ∫ a b (x 2 - x) 2 /(x 3 - 3x + 1) 2 dx. Then we get I(1/101, 1/11) = ∫ 101/100 11/10 (y 2 - y) 2 /(y 3 - 3y + 1) 2 dy/y 2 . Applying the transformation again gives that I(-100, -10) + I(1/101, 1/11) + I(101/100, 11/10) = ∫ -100 -10 (z 2 - z) 2 /(z 3 - 3z + 1) 2 (1 + (2z 2 - 2z + 1)/( (z - 1) 2 z 2 ) ) dz = ∫ -10 -100 (z 2 - z + 1) 2 /(z 3 - 3z + 1) 2 dz. At this point we are in a difficulty. It is still not obvious how to evaluate the integral explicitly. But at the same time, there is no other obvious approach. If it does have a closed form, then (az 2 + bz + c)/(z 3 - 3z + 1) looks a good candidate. Differentiating this, we find that it does in fact work for a = -1, b = 1, c = 0. So the value is K(-10) - K(-100), where K(z) = (z 2 - z)/(z 3 - 3z + 1). This is obviously rational. [In fact it evaluates to the answer given above with a little more effort.] Putnam 1993 © John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 12 Dec 1998

original.problem: 2nd Putnam 1939 Problem B5 Do either (1) or (2): (1) Prove that ∫ 1 k [x] f '(x) dx = [k] f(k) - ∑ 1 [k] f(n), where k > 1, and [z] denotes the greatest integer ≤ z. Find a similar expression for: ∫ 1 k [x 2 ] f '(x) dx. (2) A particle moves freely in a straight line except for a resistive force proportional to its speed. Its speed falls from 1,000 ft/s to 900 ft/s over 1,200 ft. Find the time taken to the nearest 0.01 s. [No calculators or log tables allowed!]
original.solution: (1) Easy. [x] is constant over the interval [i, i+1) for i an integer, so we split the range of integration to get ∫ 1 k = ∫ [k] k + ∫ 1 2 + ∫ 2 3 + ... + ∫ [k]-1 [k] . We can write down each of these integrals, collect terms and get the result. The same idea works the second integral, except that we divide at √2, √3, √4, ... , √[k 2 ], giving the result: [k 2 ] f(k) - ( f(1) + f(√2) + f(√3) + ... + f(√[k 2 ]) ). (2) Easy. 1.26 s. The equation of motion is x'' = - k x'. Integrating: x' = k A e -kt . Integrating again, and putting x(0) = 0, x = A(1 - e -kt ). Suppose T is the required time. Then from the speed e -kT = 0.9. x(T) = 1200, so A = 12000. The initial speed is 1000, so k = 1/12 and T = -12 ln 0.9. The only slight snag is that in the exam calculators did not exist and log tables were not allowed. So we have to use the expansion ln(1 + x) = x - x 2 /2 + x 3 /3 - ... , or more usefully: - ln(1 - x) = x + x 2 /2 + x 3 /3 + ... , giving T = 1.2 + 0.06 + 0.004 + 0.0003 + ... or 1.26 s. 2nd Putnam 1939 © John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 4 Sep 1999

llm_response:

2. Part (2) involves a word problem where you must derive and compute the time taken for a particle under a resistive force, which also involves calculations with logarithmic approximations.

The integral in part (1) can be verified by direct computation and property manipulation, while part (2) is a medium-difficulty problem since it involves deriving a solution through calculations without direct computational step substitutions.

Since both parts construct solutions that can be verified but do not require a formal proof beyond computation, they lean towards a classification of MEDIUM.

**Classification: MEDIUM**

original.problem: 5th ASU 1965 Problem 14 A spy-plane circles point A at a distance 10 km with speed 1000 km/h. A missile is fired towards the plane from A at the same speed and moves so that it is always on the line between A and the plane. How long does it take to hit? Solution
original.solution: : 18pi sec. Let C be the position of the spy-plane at the moment the missile is fired. Let B be the point a quarter of the way around the circle from C (in the direction the spy-plane is moving). Then the missile moves along the semi-circle on diameter AB and hits the plane at B. To see this take a point P on the quarter circle and let the line AX meet the semi-circle at Q. Let O be the center of the semicircle. The angle BOQ is twice the angle BAQ, so the arc BP is the same length as the arc BQ. Hence also the arc AQ is the same length as the arc CP. 5th ASU 1965 (C) John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 30 Sep 1998
